Company2Name: Henry Lee Company, Inc., a subsidiary of Smart & F

_prev_prog_3.Description: This is the only regulated process at the facility. It consists of various high pressure and low pressure receivers, condenser, and associated piping.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Smart & Final/Henry Lee freezer facility is a distribution center of perishable goods for Smart & Final/Henry Lees local retail centers.  The facility occupies approximately 95,000 square feet of floor space on approximately 5 acres.  The facility consists of a -10 oF freezer, a  20oF freezer, a 40 oF dock space, a future office area, a refrigeration system equipment room, an electrical room, and an office area.  The facility is located at 2850 NW 120th Terrace, Miami, Miami-Dade County, Florida.  The refrigeration system has a capacity greater than 10,000 pounds of ammonia, placing the Smart & Final/ Henry Lee freezer facility within the applicability of the RMP rule.

The ammonia refrigeration process involves cyclic compression, condensation, cooling, and expansion of anhydrous ammonia.  No chemical reaction occurs, and mass is neither added nor removed from the process; only energy (in the form of heat) is exchanged in this process.  The ammonia is in a closed system which, with the exception of the original charge, neither requires a feed stream of ammonia nor produces an ammonia derived product.  The ammonia refrigeration process is a common, well understood and universally accepted process for cold storage.  In addition to the process knowledge gained by the industrys long operation of such process equipment, the industry also has the benefit of a trade association established to address the specific needs of the ammonia refrigeration industry (the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration).  The cold storage industry, with the exception of the PSM standard, is a relatively unregulated industry by virtue of the simplicity of the refrigeration process.  The following passage illustrates this point:

"There is a large number of smaller distributors and consumers of hazardous materials, which would not ordinarily be subject to (regulation) because they do not use extremely hazardous substances in the threshold quantities that trigger application of

the standard.  Still, these facilities can benefit from an understanding of the rigorous demands of the (regulations such as the) PSM Standard by implementing some of the standards more general process safety management requirements and procedures...Examples of operations that may employ more generalized PSM techniques include: use of chlorine gas in municipal water treatment systems; ammonia based refrigeration systems; ethylene oxide sterilizers in hospitals; and anhydrous ammonia used by farmers (Dennison, 1994)."

Similarly, Smart & Final/Henry Lee has operated similar facilities for many years without incident.  In its Guidelines for Hazard Evaluation Procedures, the Center for Chemical Process Safety supports the use of procedures tailored to the complexity (or, in this case, simplicity) of the process:
Typically, when (1) the subject process has operated relatively free of accidents over a long period of time and the potential for a high-consequence accident is perceived to be low, and (2) there have been few changes to the process that would invalidate this experience base, then organizations will tend to select less exhaustive, less systematic, more experience-based HE (hazard evaluation) techniques...  (AIChE, 1992)

It is this experience base which Smart & Final/Henry Lee adds to a stable, well established process which forms the foundation for the RMP program which follows.  The RMP program, in the case of Smart & Final/Henry Lee, has provided an opportunity to examine and make beneficial changes to the facilitys operational practices and level of awareness with its employees.

The remainder of this executive summary details the offsite consequence analyses performed for this facility.

The worst case release scenario was developed based on the Model Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration developed by the EPA (Model RMP Guidance) and the EPAs Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (April, 1999).  The

former guidance is a useful resource for anhydrous ammonia refrigeration.  This guidance was written with a refrigeration facilitys routine operations and procedures in perspective; therefore, the guidance provided in document is well suited for this facilitys offsite consequence analysis (OCA).  The latter document is referred to specifically in the rule.

The rule states that the worst case release scenario should account for a release from the greatest amount held in a single vessel, taking into account administrative controls.  In the case of this facility, the modeled amount 4,003 pounds, which is the weight which corresponds to the volume of the largest vessel in the process.  No administrative controls were assumed for the model.

Ammonia is a gas at ambient temperature (77oF) though the process is enclosed with direct contact to the outdoors, and it exists as a liquid in th process by virtue of compression/refrigeration.  Therefore, the worst case scenario follows rule 68.25(c), Worst-Case Release Scenario-Toxic Gases.  This portion of the rule specifies that the release will occur over a period of ten minutes.  The rate of release is therefore calculated at 400 pounds per minute.

All OCA parameters (e.g., wind speed, atmospheric stability class, height of release, etc.) were obtained from the rule, or from one of the two referenced documents.  Smart & Final/Henry Lee has retained these parameters in a report titled Offsite Consequence Analysis, Freezer (Anhydrous Ammonia) (June, 1999).

Distance to the toxic endpoint was determined using the EPA/NOAA developed application RMPComp.  The endpoint was determined to be 0.6 mi.

The rule allows the facility to apply some knowledge of its process to model a more likely release scenario than the worst-case release scenario.  Section 68.28, Alternative Release Scenario Analysis states that at least one alternative release scenario must be considered for this process.  The OCA parameters (as specified in Sec

tion 68.22, Offsite Consequence Analysis Parameters) used in the alternative release scenario are obtained from the Model Risk Management Program Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration developed by the EPA.  The only difference between the worst-case release scenario and the alternative-release scenario is the volume of ammonia released.  Smart & Final/Henry Lee has retained these parameters in a report titled Offsite Consequence Analysis, Freezer Facility (Anhydrous Ammonia), (June, 1999).

Distance to the toxic endpoint was determined using the EPA/NOAA developed application RMPComp.  The endpoint was determined to be 0.1 mi.
